Title:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 Security Technical Implementation Guide
Description:This Security Technical Implementation Guide is published as a tool to improve the security of Department of Defense (DoD) information systems. The requirements are derived from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) 800-53 and related documents. Comments or proposed revisions to this document should be sent via email to the following address: disa.stig_spt@mail.mil.

Detailed Results

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed or new passwords are established, the new password must contain at least one upper-case character.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204407r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-010120
Identities:CCE-27200-5
SV-86527
V-71903
CCI-000192 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one upper-case character be used by setting the "ucredit" option.

Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" (or modify the line to have the required value):

ucredit = -1
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:484
Result:false
Title:Set Password ucredit Requirements
Description:The password ucredit should meet minimum requirements
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf)
    • true (All child checks must be true.)
      • true (check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth)
Tests:
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:485 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2372 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/security/pwquality.conf'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^ucredit[\s]*=[\s]*(-?\d+)(?:[\s]|$)'
  • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2373 (textfilecontent54_state)
State Requirements:
  • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', instance must be equal to '1'
  • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
    • subexpression must be less than or equal to '-1'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:480 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:true
Title:check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2368 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
  • instance must be equal to '1'
Collected Item/State Result:
[ not evaluated ]
  • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
  • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
  • filename equals 'system-auth'
  • pattern equals '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
  • instance equals '1'
  • text equals ' password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
  • line equals ' password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
  • subexpression does not exist

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed or new passwords are established, the new password must contain at least one lower-case character.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204408r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-010130
Identities:CCE-27345-8
SV-86529
V-71905
CCI-000193 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. false
Fix Text:Configure the system to require at least one lower-case character when creating or changing a password.

Add or modify the following line
in "/etc/security/pwquality.conf":

lcredit = -1
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:468
Result:false
Title:Set Password lcredit Requirements
Description:The password lcredit should meet minimum requirements
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf)
    • true (All child checks must be true.)
      • true (check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth)
Tests:
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:469 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2356 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/security/pwquality.conf'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^lcredit[\s]*=[\s]*(-?\d+)(?:[\s]|$)'
  • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2357 (textfilecontent54_state)
State Requirements:
  • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', instance must be equal to '1'
  • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
    • subexpression must be less than or equal to '-1'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:480 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:true
Title:check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2368 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
  • instance must be equal to '1'
Collected Item/State Result:
[ not evaluated ]
  • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
  • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
  • filename equals 'system-auth'
  • pattern equals '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
  • instance equals '1'
  • text equals ' password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
  • line equals ' password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
  • subexpression does not exist

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed or new passwords are assigned, the new password must contain at least one numeric character.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204409r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-010140
Identities:CCE-27214-6
SV-86531
V-71907
CCI-000194 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one numeric character be used by setting the "dcredit" option.

Add the following line to /etc/security/pwquality.conf (or modify the line to have the required value):

dcredit = -1
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:463
Result:false
Title:Set Password dcredit Requirements
Description:The password dcredit should meet minimum requirements
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf)
    • true (All child checks must be true.)
      • true (check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth)
Tests:
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:465 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2352 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/security/pwquality.conf'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^dcredit[\s]*=[\s]*(-?\d+)(?:[\s]|$)'
  • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2353 (textfilecontent54_state)
State Requirements:
  • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', instance must be equal to '1'
  • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
    • subexpression must be less than or equal to '-1'

Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:480 (textfilecontent54_test)

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed or new passwords are established, the new password must contain at least one special character.

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed a minimum of eight of the total number of characters must be changed.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204411r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-010160
Identities:CCE-26631-2
V-71911
SV-86535
CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require the change of at least eight of the total number of characters when passwords are changed by setting the "difok" option.

Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" (or modify the line to have the required value):

difok = 8

Weight:10.0

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed a minimum of four character classes must be changed.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204412r603261_rule

Version:RHEL-07-010170
Identities:CCE-27115-5
V-71913

CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require the change of at least four character classes when passwords are changed by setting the "minclass" option.

minclass = 4

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed the number of repeating consecutive characters must not be more than three characters.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204413r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-010180
Identities:CCE-27333-4
SV-86539
V-71915
CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require the change of the number of repeating consecutive characters when passwords are changed by setting the "maxrepeat" option.

Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf conf" (or modify the line to have the required value):

maxrepeat = 3

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed the number of repeating characters of the same character class must not be more than four characters.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204414r809186_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-010190
Identities:CCE-27512-3
SV-86541
V-71917

Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require the change of the number of repeating characters of the same character class when passwords are changed by setting the "maxclassrepeat" option.

Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" conf (or modify the line to have the required value):

maxclassrepeat = 4

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that passwords for new users are restricted to a 24 hours/1 day minimum lifetime.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204418r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-010230
Identities:CCE-27002-5
V-71925
SV-86549
CCI-000198 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
Description: Enforcing a minimum password lifetime helps to prevent repeated password changes to defeat the password reuse or history enforcement requirement. If users are allowed to immediately and continually change their password, the password could be repeatedly changed in a short period of time to defeat the organization's policy regarding password reuse. false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enforce 24 hours/1 day as the minimum password lifetime.

Add the following line in "/etc/login.defs" (or modify the line to have the required value):

PASS_MIN_DAYS 1
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:455
Result:false
Title:Set Password Expiration Parameters
Description:The minimum password age policy should be set appropriately.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (The value of PASS_MIN_DAYS should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs)
Tests:
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:456 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:The value of PASS_MIN_DAYS should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:3730 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/login.defs'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*PASS_MIN_DAYS\s+(\d+)\s*$'
  • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2346 (textfilecontent54_state)
State Requirements:
  • for check = 'all', subexpression, at least one of the following must be true:
    • subexpression must be greater than or equal to '1'
Collected Item/State Result:
[ false ]
  • filepath equals '/etc/login.defs'
  • path equals '/etc'
  • filename equals 'login.defs'
  • pattern equals '^\s*PASS_MIN_DAYS\s+(\d+)\s*$'
  • instance equals '1'
  • text equals 'PASS_MIN_DAYS 0'
  • line equals 'PASS_MIN_DAYS 0'
  • subexpression equals '0'
Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
subexpression

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that passwords are restricted to a 24 hours/1 day minimum lifetime.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204419r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-010240
Identities:SV-86551
V-71927
CCI-000198 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
Description: Enforcing a minimum password lifetime helps to prevent repeated password changes to defeat the password reuse or history enforcement requirement. If users are allowed to immediately and continually change their password, the password could be repeatedly changed in a short period of time to defeat the organization's policy regarding password reuse. false
Fix Text:Configure non-compliant accounts to enforce a 24 hours/1 day minimum password lifetime:

# chage -m 1 [user]
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:

Description:Passwords must be restricted to a 1 day minimum lifetime.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (Passwords for interactive users must be restricted to a 1 day minimum lifetime.)
    • true (no shadow entries with null minimum password ages)
Tests:

    • username must be equal to 'centos'

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that passwords for new users are restricted to a 60-day maximum lifetime.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204420r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-010250
Identities:CCE-27051-2
V-71929
SV-86553
CCI-000199 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
Description: Any password, no matter how complex, can eventually be cracked. Therefore, passwords need to be changed periodically. If the operating system does not limit the lifetime of passwords and force users to change their passwords, there is the risk that the operating system passwords could be compromised. false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enforce a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction.

Add the following line in "/etc/login.defs" (or modify the line to have the required value):

PASS_MAX_DAYS 60
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:453
Result:false
Title:Set Password Expiration Parameters
Description:The maximum password age policy should meet minimum requirements.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (The value of PASS_MAX_DAYS should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs)
Tests:
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:454 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:The value of PASS_MAX_DAYS should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:3729 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/login.defs'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*PASS_MAX_DAYS\s+(\d+)\s*$'
  • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2344 (textfilecontent54_state)
State Requirements:
  • for check = 'all', subexpression, at least one of the following must be true:
    • subexpression must be less than or equal to '60'
Collected Item/State Result:
[ false ]
  • filepath equals '/etc/login.defs'
  • path equals '/etc'
  • filename equals 'login.defs'
  • pattern equals '^\s*PASS_MAX_DAYS\s+(\d+)\s*$'
  • instance equals '1'
  • text equals 'PASS_MAX_DAYS 99999'
  • line equals 'PASS_MAX_DAYS 99999'
  • subexpression equals '99999'
Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
subexpression

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that existing passwords are restricted to a 60-day maximum lifetime.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204421r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-010260
Identities:V-71931
SV-86555
CCI-000199 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
Description: Any password, no matter how complex, can eventually be cracked. Therefore, passwords need to be changed periodically. If the operating system does not limit the lifetime of passwords and force users to change their passwords, there is the risk that the operating system passwords could be compromised. false
Fix Text:Configure non-compliant accounts to enforce a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction.

# chage -M 60 [user]

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that passwords are prohibited from reuse for a minimum of five generations.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204422r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-010270
Identities:CCE-26923-3
V-71933
SV-86557
CCI-000200 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (e); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (e))
Description: Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. If the information system or application allows the user to consecutively reuse their password when that password has exceeded its defined lifetime, the end result is a password that is not changed per policy requirements. false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to prohibit password reuse for a minimum of five generations.

Add the following line in "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" and "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" (or modify the line to have the required value):

password requisite pam_pwhistory.so use_authtok remember=5 retry=3

Note: Manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authconfig" program. The "authconfig" program should not be used to update the configurations listed in this requirement.
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:486
Result:false
Title:Limit Password Reuse
Description:The passwords to remember should be set correctly.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
    • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
      • false (Test if remember attribute of pam_unix.so is set correctly in /etc/pam.d/system-auth)
      • false (Test if remember attribute of pam_pwhistory.so is set correctly in /etc/pam.d/system-auth)
    • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
      • false (Test if remember attribute of pam_unix.so is set correctly in /etc/pam.d/password-auth)
      • false (Test if remember attribute of pam_pwhistory.so is set correctly in /etc/pam.d/password-auth)
Tests:
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:487 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:Test if remember attribute of pam_unix.so is set correctly in /etc/pam.d/system-auth
Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2374 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:sufficient)|(?:required))\s+pam_unix\.so[^#\n\r]*remember=([0-9]*).*$'
  • instance must be equal to '1'
State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2375 (textfilecontent54_state)
State Requirements:
  • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
    • subexpression must be greater than or equal to '5'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:488 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:Test if remember attribute of pam_pwhistory.so is set correctly in /etc/pam.d/system-auth
Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).

  • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:requisite)|(?:required))\s+pam_pwhistory\.so[^#\n\r]*remember=([0-9]*).*$'
  • instance must be equal to '1'
State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2375 (textfilecontent54_state)
State Requirements:
  • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
    • subexpression must be greater than or equal to '5'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:48700 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:Test if remember attribute of pam_unix.so is set correctly in /etc/pam.d/password-auth
Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).

  • instance must be equal to '1'

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that passwords are a minimum of 15 characters in length.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204423r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-010280
Identities:CCE-27293-0
V-71935
SV-86559
CCI-000205 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (i); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
Description: The shorter the password, the lower the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. Password length is one factor of several that helps to determine strength and how long it takes to crack a password. Use of more characters in a password helps to exponentially increase the time and/or resources required to compromise the password. false
Fix Text:Configure operating system to enforce a minimum 15-character password length.

Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" (or modify the line to have the required value):

minlen = 15
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:476
Result:false
Title:Set Password minlen Requirements
Description:The password minlen should meet minimum requirements
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf)
    • true (All child checks must be true.)
      • true (check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth)
Tests:
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:477 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2364 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/security/pwquality.conf'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^minlen[\s]*=[\s]*(-?\d+)(?:[\s]|$)'
  • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2365 (textfilecontent54_state)
State Requirements:
  • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', instance must be equal to '1'
  • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
    • subexpression must be greater than or equal to '15'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:480 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:true
Title:check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2368 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
  • instance must be equal to '1'
Collected Item/State Result:
[ not evaluated ]
  • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
  • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
  • filename equals 'system-auth'
  • pattern equals '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
  • instance equals '1'
  • text equals ' password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
  • line equals ' password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
  • subexpression does not exist

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not allow accounts configured with blank or null passwords.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204424r809187_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-010290
Identities:CCE-27286-4
V-71937
SV-86561
CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
Description: If an account has an empty password, anyone could log on and run commands with the privileges of that account. Accounts with empty passwords should never be used in operational environments. false
Fix Text:If an account is configured for password authentication but does not have an assigned password, it may be possible to log on to the account without authenticating.

Remove any instances of the "nullok" option in "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" and "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" to prevent logons with empty passwords.

Note: Manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authconfig" program. The "authconfig" program should not be used to update the configurations listed in this requirement.
Severity:high
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1229
Result:false
Title:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not allow accounts configured with blank or null passwords.
Description:The file /etc/pam.d/system-auth should not contain the nullok option
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (make sure nullok is not used in /etc/pam.d/system-auth)
    • false (make sure nullok is not used in /etc/pam.d/password-auth)
Tests:
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1230 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:make sure nullok is not used in /etc/pam.d/system-auth
Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2964 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^[^#]*\s*nullok\s*'
  • instance must be equal to '1'
Collected Item/State Result:
[ not evaluated ]
  • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
  • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
  • filename equals 'system-auth'
  • pattern equals '^[^#]*\s*nullok\s*'
  • instance equals '1'
  • text equals 'auth required pam_env.so auth required pam_faildelay.so delay=2000000 auth sufficient pam_unix.so nullok try_first_pass auth requisite pam_succeed_if.so uid >= 1000 quiet_success auth required pam_deny.so account required pam_unix.so account sufficient pam_localuser.so account sufficient pam_succeed_if.so uid < 1000 quiet account required pam_permit.so password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type= password sufficient pam_unix.so sha512 shadow nullok '
  • line equals 'auth required pam_env.so auth required pam_faildelay.so delay=2000000 auth sufficient pam_unix.so nullok try_first_pass auth requisite pam_succeed_if.so uid >= 1000 quiet_success auth required pam_deny.so account required pam_unix.so account sufficient pam_localuser.so account sufficient pam_succeed_if.so uid < 1000 quiet account required pam_permit.so password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type= password sufficient pam_unix.so sha512 shadow nullok '
  • subexpression does not exist
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:123000 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:make sure nullok is not used in /etc/pam.d/password-auth
Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:296400 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/password-auth'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^[^#]*\s*nullok\s*'
  • instance must be equal to '1'
Collected Item/State Result:
[ not evaluated ]
  • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/password-auth'
  • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
  • filename equals 'password-auth'
  • pattern equals '^[^#]*\s*nullok\s*'
  • instance equals '1'
  • text equals 'auth required pam_env.so auth required pam_faildelay.so delay=2000000 auth sufficient pam_unix.so nullok try_first_pass auth requisite pam_succeed_if.so uid >= 1000 quiet_success auth required pam_deny.so account required pam_unix.so account sufficient pam_localuser.so account sufficient pam_succeed_if.so uid < 1000 quiet account required pam_permit.so password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type= password sufficient pam_unix.so sha512 shadow nullok '
  • line equals 'auth required pam_env.so auth required pam_faildelay.so delay=2000000 auth sufficient pam_unix.so nullok try_first_pass auth requisite pam_succeed_if.so uid >= 1000 quiet_success auth required pam_deny.so account required pam_unix.so account sufficient pam_localuser.so account sufficient pam_succeed_if.so uid < 1000 quiet account required pam_permit.so password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type= password sufficient pam_unix.so sha512 shadow nullok '
  • subexpression does not exist
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must disable account identifiers (individuals, groups, roles, and devices) if the password expires.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204426r809190_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-010310
Identities:CCE-27471-2
SV-86565
V-71941
CCI-000795 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-4 e; NIST SP 800-53A: IA-4.1 (iii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-4 e)
Description: Inactive identifiers pose a risk to systems and applications because attackers may exploit an inactive identifier and potentially obtain undetected access to the system. Owners of inactive accounts will not notice if unauthorized access to their user account has been obtained.

Operating systems need to track periods of inactivity and disable application identifiers after 35 days of inactivity. false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to disable account identifiers (individuals, groups, roles, and devices) 35 days after the password expires.

Add the following line to "/etc/default/useradd" (or modify the line to have the required value):

INACTIVE=35
DoD recommendation is 35 days, but a lower value is acceptable. The value "-1" will disable this feature, and "0" will disable the account immediately after the password expires.
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:443
Result:false
Title:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must disable account identifiers (individuals, groups, roles, and devices) if the password expires.
Description:Inactive identifiers pose a risk to systems and applications because attackers may exploit an inactive identifier and potentially obtain undetected access to the system. Owners of inactive accounts will not notice if unauthorized access to their user account has been obtained. Operating systems need to track periods of inactivity and disable application identifiers after zero35 days of inactivity.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (the value INACTIVE parameter should be set appropriately in /etc/default/useradd)
Tests:
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:444 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:the value INACTIVE parameter should be set appropriately in /etc/default/useradd
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
State Operator:All item-state comparisons must be true.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2333 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/default/useradd'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*INACTIVE\s*=\s*(\d+)\s*$'
  • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2334 (textfilecontent54_state)
State Requirements:
  • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than or equal to '35'
State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2335 (textfilecontent54_state)
State Requirements:
  • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than or equal to '0'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that users must provide a password for privilege escalation.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204429r833190_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-010340
Identities:CCE-80351-0
V-71947
SV-86571
CCI-002038 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-11)
Description: Without re-authentication, users may access resources or perform tasks for which they do not have authorization.

When operating systems provide the capability to escalate a functional capability, it is critical the user re-authenticate.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00156, SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00157, SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00158 false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require users to supply a password for privilege escalation.

Check the configuration of the "/etc/sudoers" file with the following command:
$ sudo visudo

Remove any occurrences of "NOPASSWD" tags in the file.

Check the configuration of the /etc/sudoers.d/* files with the following command:
$ sudo grep -ir nopasswd /etc/sudoers.d

Remove any occurrences of "NOPASSWD" tags in the file.
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:176
Result:false
Title:Ensure NOPASSWD Is Not Used in Sudo
Description:Checks sudo usage without password
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • true (NOPASSWD does not exist /etc/sudoers)
    • false (NOPASSWD does not exist in /etc/sudoers.d)
Tests:

Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2108 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/sudoers'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^(?!#).*[\s]+NOPASSWD[\s]*\:.*$'
  • instance must be equal to '1'
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:178 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:NOPASSWD does not exist in /etc/sudoers.d
Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2109 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • path must be equal to '/etc/sudoers.d'
  • filename must match the pattern '^.*$'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^(?!#).*[\s]+NOPASSWD[\s]*\:.*$'
  • instance must be equal to '1'
Collected Item/State Result:

  • filepath equals '/etc/sudoers.d/90-cloud-init-users'
  • path equals '/etc/sudoers.d'
  • filename equals '90-cloud-init-users'
  • pattern equals '^(?!#).*[\s]+NOPASSWD[\s]*\:.*$'
  • instance equals '1'
  • text equals 'centos ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD:ALL'
  • line equals 'centos ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD:ALL'
  • subexpression does not exist
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the delay between logon prompts following a failed console logon attempt is at least four seconds.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204431r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-010430
Identities:CCE-80352-8
SV-86575
V-71951
CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
Description: Configuring the operating system to implement organization-wide security implementation guides and security checklists verifies compliance with federal standards and establishes a common security baseline across DoD that reflects the most restrictive security posture consistent with operational requirements.

Configuration settings are the set of parameters that can be changed in hardware, software, or firmware components of the system that affect the security posture and/or functionality of the system. Security-related parameters are those parameters impacting the security state of the system, including the parameters required to satisfy other security control requirements. Security-related parameters include, for example, registry settings; account, file, and directory permission settings; and settings for functions, ports, protocols, services, and remote connections. false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enforce a delay of at least four seconds between logon prompts following a failed console logon attempt.

Modify the "/etc/login.defs" file to set the "FAIL_DELAY" parameter to "4" or greater:

FAIL_DELAY 4
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899

Result:false
Title:Ensure that FAIL_DELAY is Configured in /etc/login.defs
Description:The delay between failed authentication attempts should be set for all users specified in /etc/login.defs
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (check FAIL_DELAY in /etc/login.defs)
Tests:
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:102 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:check FAIL_DELAY in /etc/login.defs
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2055 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/login.defs'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*FAIL_DELAY[\s]+([^#\s]*)'
  • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2056 (textfilecontent54_state)
State Requirements:
  • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
    • subexpression must be greater than or equal to '4'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating systems version 7.2 or newer with a Basic Input/Output System (BIOS) must require authentication upon booting into single-user and maintenance modes.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204438r744095_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-010482
Identities:CCE-27309-4
SV-95717
V-81005
CCI-000213 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-3)
Description: If the system does not require valid authentication before it boots into single-user or maintenance mode, anyone who invokes single-user or maintenance mode is granted privileged access to all files on the system. GRUB 2 is the default boot loader for RHEL 7 and is designed to require a password to boot into single-user mode or make modifications to the boot menu. false
Fix Text:Configure the system to encrypt the boot password for the grub superusers account with the grub2-setpassword command, which creates/overwrites the /boot/grub2/user.cfg file.

Generate an encrypted grub2 password for the grub superusers account with the following command:

$ sudo grub2-setpassword
Enter password:
Confirm password:
Severity:high
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:

Result:false
Title:Set Boot Loader Password (BIOS) for RHEL 7.2 and up
Description:The grub2 boot loader should have password protection enabled.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
    • false (All child checks must be true.)
      • false (make sure a password is defined in /boot/grub2/user.cfg)
      • true (superuser is defined in /boot/grub2/grub.cfg files.)
    • false (Running RHEL 7.0 or 7.1?)
    • false (/boot/grub2/grub.cfg does not exist)

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that a file integrity tool verifies the baseline operating system configuration at least weekly.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204445r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-020030
Identities:CCE-26952-2
SV-86597
V-71973
CCI-001744 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-3 (5); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-3 (5))
Description: Unauthorized changes to the baseline configuration could make the system vulnerable to various attacks or allow unauthorized access to the operating system. Changes to operating system configurations can have unintended side effects, some of which may be relevant to security.

Detecting such changes and providing an automated response can help avoid unintended, negative consequences that could ultimately affect the security state of the operating system. The operating system's Information Management Officer (IMO)/Information System Security Officer (ISSO) and System Administrators (SAs) must be notified via email and/or monitoring system trap when there is an unauthorized modification of a configuration item. false
Fix Text:Configure the file integrity tool to run automatically on the system at least weekly. The following example output is generic. It will set cron to run AIDE daily, but other file integrity tools may be used:

# more /etc/cron.daily/aide
#!/bin/bash

/usr/sbin/aide --check | /bin/mail -s "$HOSTNAME - Daily aide integrity check run" root@sysname.mil
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:525
Result:false
Title:Configure Periodic Execution of AIDE
Description:By default, AIDE does not install itself for periodic execution. Periodically running AIDE is necessary to reveal unexpected changes in installed files.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
      • false (run aide daily with /etc/crontab)
      • false (run aide daily with /etc/cron.d)
      • false (run aide daily with /var/spool/cron/root)
      • false (run aide daily with cron.daily)
      • false (run aide daily with cron.weekly)
      • false (run aide daily with cron.hourly)
    • false (All child checks must be true.)
      • false (package aide is installed)
Tests:

Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8659701 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • path must be equal to '/etc/cron.hourly'
  • filename must match the pattern '^.+$'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^[ \t]*/usr/sbin/aide[ \t]*\-\-check(?:[\s]+|[\>\|]|$)'
  • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1249 (rpminfo_test)
Result:false
Title:package aide is installed
Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2981 (rpminfo_object)
Object Requirements:
  • name must be equal to 'aide'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must prevent the installation of software, patches, service packs, device drivers, or operating system components of local packages without verification they have been digitally signed using a certificate that is issued by a Certificate Authority (CA) that is recognized and approved by the organization.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204448r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-020060
Identities:CCE-80347-8
V-71979
SV-86603
CCI-001749 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-5 (3))
Description: Changes to any software components can have significant effects on the overall security of the operating system. This requirement ensures the software has not been tampered with and that it has been provided by a trusted vendor.

Accordingly, patches, service packs, device drivers, or operating system components must be signed with a certificate recognized and approved by the organization.

Verifying the authenticity of the software prior to installation validates the integrity of the patch or upgrade received from a vendor. This verifies the software has not been tampered with and that it has been provided by a trusted vendor. Self-signed certificates are disallowed by this requirement. The operating system should not have to verify the software again. This requirement does not mandate DoD certificates for this purpose; however, the certificate used to verify the software must be from an approved CA. false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to verify the signature of local packages prior to install by setting the following option in the "/etc/yum.conf" file:

localpkg_gpgcheck=1
Severity:high
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:110
Result:false
Title:Ensure gpgcheck Enabled for Local Packages
Description:The localpkg_gpgcheck option should be used to ensure that checking of an RPM package's signature always occurs prior to its installation.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (check value of localpkg_gpgcheck in /etc/yum.conf)
Tests:
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:111 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:check value of localpkg_gpgcheck in /etc/yum.conf
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2062 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/yum.conf'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*localpkg_gpgcheck\s*=\s*(\S+)\s*$'
  • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:11100 (textfilecontent54_state)
State Requirements:
  • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^(1|True|yes)$'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured to disable USB mass storage.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204449r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-020100
Identities:SV-86607
V-71983
CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
CCI-000778 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-3; NIST SP 800-53A: IA-3.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-3)
CCI-001958 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-3)
Description: USB mass storage permits easy introduction of unknown devices, thereby facilitating malicious activity.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000114-GPOS-00059, SRG-OS-000378-GPOS-00163, SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227 false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to disable the ability to use the USB Storage kernel module.

Create a file under "/etc/modprobe.d" with the following command:

# touch /etc/modprobe.d/usb-storage.conf

Add the following line to the created file:

install usb-storage /bin/true

Configure the operating system to disable the ability to use USB mass storage devices.

# vi /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist.conf

Add or update the line:

blacklist usb-storage
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1141
Result:false
Title:Disable usb-storage Kernel Module
Description:The kernel module usb-storage should be disabled.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (kernel module usb-storage disabled)
    • false (kernel module usb-storage blacklisted in /etc/modprobe.d)
Tests:
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1142 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:kernel module usb-storage disabled
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2892 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • path must be equal to '/etc/modprobe.d'
  • filename must match the pattern '^.*\.conf$'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*install\s+usb-storage\s+(\S+)\s*$'
  • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:8660700 (textfilecontent54_state)
State Requirements:
  • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '/bin/true'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8660700 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:kernel module usb-storage blacklisted in /etc/modprobe.d
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8660700 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • path must be equal to '/etc/modprobe.d'
  • filename must match the pattern '^.*\.conf$'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*blacklist\s+usb-storage\s*$'
  • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the Datagram Congestion Control Protocol (DCCP) kernel module is disabled unless required.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204450r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-020101
Identities:V-77821
SV-92517
CCI-001958 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-3)
Description: Disabling DCCP protects the system against exploitation of any flaws in the protocol implementation. false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to disable the ability to use the DCCP kernel module.

Create a file under "/etc/modprobe.d" with the following command:

# touch /etc/modprobe.d/dccp.conf

Add the following line to the created file:

install dccp /bin/true

Ensure that the DCCP module is blacklisted:

# vi /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist.conf

Add or update the line:

blacklist dccp
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA

    • true (kernel module dccp blacklisted in /etc/modprobe.d)

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must remove all software components after updated versions have been installed.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204452r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-020200
Identities:CCE-80346-0
V-71987
SV-86611
CCI-002617 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: SI-2 (6); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: SI-2 (6))
Description: Previous versions of software components that are not removed from the information system after updates have been installed may be exploited by adversaries. Some information technology products may remove older versions of software automatically from the information system. false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to remove all software components after updated versions have been installed.

Set the "clean_requirements_on_remove" option to "1" in the "/etc/yum.conf" file:

clean_requirements_on_remove=1
Severity:low
Weight:10.0

Description:The clean_requirements_on_remove option should be used to ensure that old versions of software components are removed after updating.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (check value of clean_requirements_on_remove in /etc/yum.conf)
Tests:

  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/yum.conf'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*clean_requirements_on_remove\s*=\s*(\S+)\s*$'
  • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be a vendor supported release.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204458r744100_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-020250
Identities:CCE-80349-4
SV-86621
V-71997
CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
Description: An operating system release is considered "supported" if the vendor continues to provide security patches for the product. With an unsupported release, it will not be possible to resolve security issues discovered in the system software.

Red Hat offers the Extended Update Support (EUS) Add-On to a Red Hat Enterprise Linux subscription, for a fee, for those customers who wish to standardize on a specific minor release for an extended period. RHEL 7.7 marks the final minor release that EUS will be available, while 7.9 is the final minor release overall. false
Fix Text:Upgrade to a supported version of the operating system.
Severity:high
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:169
Result:false
Title:RHEL-07-020250 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be a vendor supported release
Description:An operating system release is considered "supported" if the vendor continues to provide security patches for the product. With an unsupported release, it will not be possible to resolve security issues discovered in the system software.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (Supported RHEL7 minor version)
    • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (redhat-release-virtualization-host RPM package is installed)
        • false (RHEVH base RHEL is version 7)
      • false (redhat-release-client is version 7)
      • false (redhat-release-workstation is version 7)
      • false (redhat-release-server is version 7)
      • false (redhat-release-computenode is version 7)

  • pattern must match the pattern '^Red Hat Enterprise Linux.*release\s+(\S+)\s+'
  • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

  • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '7.9'

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that all world-writable directories are group-owned by root, sys, bin, or an application group.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204487r744106_rule
Result:Error
Version:RHEL-07-021030
Identities:CCE-80136-5
V-72047
SV-86671
CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
Description: If a world-writable directory is not group-owned by root, sys, bin, or an application Group Identifier (GID), unauthorized users may be able to modify files created by others.

The only authorized public directories are those temporary directories supplied with the system or those designed to be temporary file repositories. The setting is normally reserved for directories used by the system and by users for temporary file storage, (e.g., /tmp), and for directories requiring global read/write access. false
Fix Text:All directories in local partitions which are world-writable should be group-owned by root or another system account. If any world-writable directories are not group-owned by a system account, this should be investigated. Following this, the directories should be deleted or assigned to an appropriate group.
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1009
Result:error
Title:Find world writable directories not group-owned by a system account
Description:All world writable directories should be group-owned by a system user.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • error (All child checks must be true.) (negated)
    • error (check for local directories that are world writable and have gid greater than or equal to 1000)
Tests:
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1010 (file_test)
Result:error
Title:check for local directories that are world writable and have gid greater than or equal to 1000
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2783 (file_object)
Object Requirements:
  • behavior requirements:
    • recurse = directories
    • recurse_direction = down
    • recurse_file_system = local
  • path must be equal to '/'
Include Items If:
  • group_id is greater than or equal to '1000'
  • owrite equals 'true'
State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2784 (file_state)
State Requirements:
  • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', group_id must be greater than or equal to '1000'
  • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', owrite must be equal to 'true'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that a separate file system is used for user home directories (such as /home or an equivalent).

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204493r603840_rule

Version:RHEL-07-021310

SV-86683

CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
Description: The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing. false
Fix Text:Migrate the "/home" directory onto a separate file system/partition.
Severity:low
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7

Result:false
Title:Ensure /home Located On Separate Partition
Description:If user home directories will be stored locally, create a separate partition for /home. If /home will be mounted from another system such as an NFS server, then creating a separate partition is not necessary at this time, and the mountpoint can instead be configured later.
Class:compliance

  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (/home on own partition)

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must use a separate file system for /var.

Description: The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing. false
Fix Text:Migrate the "/var" path onto a separate file system.

Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7

Definitions:

Result:false
Title:Ensure /var Located On Separate Partition
Description:Ensuring that /var is mounted on its own partition enables the setting of more restrictive mount options, which is used as temporary storage by many program, particularly system services such as daemons. It is not uncommon for the /var directory to contain world-writable directories, installed by other software packages.

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must use a separate file system for the system audit data path.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204495r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-021330
Identities:SV-86687
V-72063
CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
Description: The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing. false
Fix Text:Migrate the system audit data path onto a separate file system.
Severity:low
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1319
Result:false
Title:Ensure /var/log/audit Located On Separate Partition
Description:Audit logs are stored in the /var/log/audit directory. Ensure that it has its own partition or logical volume. Make absolutely certain that it is large enough to store all audit logs that will be created by the auditing daemon.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (check for /var/log/audit partition)
    • false (/var/log/audit configured in /etc/fstab)

Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8668700 (textfilecontent54_test)

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must use a separate file system for /tmp (or equivalent).

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204496r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-021340
Identities:CCE-27173-4
SV-86689
V-72065
CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
Description: The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing. false
Fix Text:Start the "tmp.mount" service with the following command:

# systemctl enable tmp.mount

OR

Edit the "/etc/fstab" file and ensure the "/tmp" directory is defined in the fstab with a device and mount point.
Severity:low
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:86689
Result:false
Title:The system must use a separate file system for /tmp (or equivalent).
Description:The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing.
Class:compliance

  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (check for /tmp)

Check:Result is based on check existence only.

  • mount_point does not exist
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must implement NIST FIPS-validated cryptography for the following: to provision digital signatures, to generate cryptographic hashes, and to protect data requiring data-at-rest protections in accordance with applicable federal laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, and standards.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204497r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-021350
Identities:CCE-80359-3
SV-86691
V-72067
CCI-000068 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-17 (2); NIST SP 800-53A: AC-17 (2).1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-17 (2); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-17 (2))
CCI-001199 (NIST SP 800-53: SC-28; NIST SP 800-53A: SC-28.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: SC-28; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: SC-28)
CCI-002450 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: SC-13; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: SC-13 b)
CCI-002476 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: SC-28 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: SC-28 (1))
Description: Use of weak or untested encryption algorithms undermines the purposes of using encryption to protect data. The operating system must implement cryptographic modules adhering to the higher standards approved by the federal government since this provides assurance they have been tested and validated.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000033-GPOS-00014, SRG-OS-000185-GPOS-00079, SRG-OS-000396-GPOS-00176, SRG-OS-000405-GPOS-00184, SRG-OS-000478-GPOS-00223 false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to implement DoD-approved encryption by installing the dracut-fips package.

To enable strict FIPS compliance, the fips=1 kernel option needs to be added to the kernel command line during system installation so key generation is done with FIPS-approved algorithms and continuous monitoring tests in place.

Configure the operating system to implement DoD-approved encryption by following the steps below:

The fips=1 kernel option needs to be added to the kernel command line during system installation so that key generation is done with FIPS-approved algorithms and continuous monitoring tests in place. Users should also ensure that the system has plenty of entropy during the installation process by moving the mouse around, or if no mouse is available, ensuring that many keystrokes are typed. The recommended amount of keystrokes is 256 and more. Less than 256 keystrokes may generate a non-unique key.

Install the dracut-fips package with the following command:

# yum install dracut-fips

Recreate the "initramfs" file with the following command:

Note: This command will overwrite the existing "initramfs" file.

# dracut -f

Modify the kernel command line of the current kernel in the "grub.cfg" file by adding the following option to the GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX key in the "/etc/default/grub" file and then rebuild the "grub.cfg" file:

fips=1

Changes to "/etc/default/grub" require rebuilding the "grub.cfg" file as follows:

On BIOS-based machines, use the following command:

# grub2-mkconfig -o /boot/grub2/grub.cfg

On UEFI-based machines, use the following command:

# grub2-mkconfig -o /boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg

If /boot or /boot/efi reside on separate partitions, the kernel parameter boot= must be added to the kernel command line. You can identify a partition by running the df /boot or df /boot/efi command:

# df /boot
Filesystem 1K-blocks Used Available Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda1 495844 53780 416464 12% /boot

To ensure the "boot=" configuration option will work even if device naming changes occur between boots, identify the universally unique identifier (UUID) of the partition with the following command:

# blkid /dev/sda1
/dev/sda1: UUID="05c000f1-a213-759e-c7a2-f11b7424c797" TYPE="ext4"

For the example above, append the following string to the kernel command line:

boot=UUID=05c000f1-a213-759e-c7a2-f11b7424c797

If the file /etc/system-fips does not exists, recreate it:

# touch /etc/ system-fips

Reboot the system for the changes to take effect.
Severity:high
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:126
Result:false
Title:Enable FIPS Mode in GRUB2
Description:Look for argument fips=1 in the kernel line in /etc/default/grub.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
      • false (check for fips=1 in /etc/default/grub via GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX)
      • false (check for fips=1 in /etc/default/grub via GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT)
    • false (check for fips=1 in grub.cfg)
    • false (check for 1 in /proc/sys/crypto/fips_enabled)
    • true (check for fips=0 in /etc/default/grub)
    • false (/etc/system-fips exists)
    • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (redhat-release-virtualization-host RPM package is installed)
        • false (RHEVH base RHEL is version 7)
      • false (redhat-release-client is version 7)
      • false (redhat-release-workstation is version 7)
      • false (redhat-release-server is version 7)
      • false (redhat-release-computenode is version 7)
    • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
      • false (Tests whether prelinking is disabled)
      • true (All child checks must be true.)
        • true (package prelink is removed)
    • false (All child checks must be true.)
      • false (package dracut-fips is installed)

  • name must be equal to 'dracut-fips'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that auditing is configured to produce records containing information to establish what type of events occurred, where the events occurred, the source of the events, and the outcome of the events. These audit records must also identify individual identities of group account users.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204503r603261_rule
Result:Fail
Version:RHEL-07-030000
Identities:CCE-27407-6
SV-86703
V-72079
CCI-000126 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-2 d; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-2.1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-2 d; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-2 c)
CCI-000131 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 b)
Description: Without establishing what type of events occurred, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events leading up to an outage or attack.

Audit record content that may be necessary to satisfy this requirement includes, for example, time stamps, source and destination addresses, user/process identifiers, event descriptions, success/fail indications, filenames involved, and access control or flow control rules invoked.

Associating event types with detected events in the operating system audit logs provides a means of investigating an attack; recognizing resource utilization or capacity thresholds; or identifying an improperly configured operating system.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000038-GPOS-00016, SRG-OS-000039-GPOS-00017, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00021, SRG-OS-000254-GPOS-00095, SRG-OS-000255-GPOS-00096 false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to produce audit records containing information to establish when (date and time) the events occurred.

Enable the auditd service with the following command:

# systemctl start auditd.service
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:86703
Result:false
Title:The audit service must be running.
Description:Auditing must be configured to produce records containing information to establish what type of events occurred, where the events occurred, the source of the events, and the outcome of the events.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • false (All child checks must be true.)
    • false (check for auditd)
Tests:
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8670300 (process58_test)
Result:false
Title:check for auditd
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8670300 (process58_object)
Object Requirements:
  • command_line must match the pattern '[\00]*\/sbin\/auditd[\00]*'
  • pid must be greater than '1'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must shut down upon audit processing failure, unless availability is an overriding concern. If availability is a concern, the system must alert the designated staff (System Administrator [SA] and Information System Security Officer [ISSO] at a minimum) in the event of an audit processing failure.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204504r603261_rule
Result:Error
Version:RHEL-07-030010
Identities:CCE-80381-7
V-72081
SV-86705
CCI-000139 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-5 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-5.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-5 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-5 a)
Description: It is critical for the appropriate personnel to be aware if a system is at risk of failing to process audit logs as required. Without this notification, the security personnel may be unaware of an impending failure of the audit capability, and system operation may be adversely affected.

Audit processing failures include software/hardware errors, failures in the audit capturing mechanisms, and audit storage capacity being reached or exceeded.

This requirement applies to each audit data storage repository (i.e., distinct information system component where audit records are stored), the centralized audit storage capacity of organizations (i.e., all audit data storage repositories combined), or both.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000046-GPOS-00022, SRG-OS-000047-GPOS-00023 false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to shut down in the event of an audit processing failure.

Add or correct the option to shut down the operating system with the following command:

# auditctl -f 2

Edit the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file and add the following line:

-f 2

If availability has been determined to be more important, and this decision is documented with the ISSO, configure the operating system to notify system administration staff and ISSO staff in the event of an audit processing failure with the following command:

# auditctl -f 1

Edit the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file and add the following line:

-f 1

Kernel log monitoring must also be configured to properly alert designated staff.

The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:776
Result:error
Title:Shutdown System When Auditing Failures Occur
Description:The system will shutdown when auditing fails.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • error (One or more child checks must be true.)
    • error (All child checks must be true.)
      • error (audit augenrules configuration shutdown)
      • true (All child checks must be true.)
        • true (audit augenrules)
    • false (All child checks must be true.)
      • false (audit auditctl configuration shutdown)
      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (audit auditctl)
